column1: At 4:15 there was an attack "simultaneously" by British and German destroyers which resulted in a lively fight
column2: but no damage to any of the capital ships. Yet the possibilities of such torpedo attacks were so evident
column3: here and later in the battle
column4: that the destroyer at once attained a greater value as an auxiliary of the battleship. It should also be noted that German submarines were reported present at this stage
column5: but they accomplished nothing against the screened fighting ships. A British airplane had been sent up from a mother ship just before the engagement
column6: though Admiral Beatty reports that it was forced to fly low on account of the clouds
column7: and had a hard task "to identify four enemy light cruisers." There was apparently no chance of a wide observation that would have warned Admiral Beatty of the approaching German High Seas Fleet. In this short hour were concentrated many new problems of naval warfare.
